docs.lead_paragraph: For several decades, experts on heart disease have promoted a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet as most effective in warding off the leading killer of Americans. But in recent years, new evidence has brought this advice into question.

headline.main: Dietary Advice Takes On Mediterranean Flavor

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on rcent studies showing that that Mediterranean diet--one rich in vegetables and fruits, whole grains, nuts, unsaturated vegetable oils and protein derived from fish, beans and chicken--is heart-healthy; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For several decades, experts on heart disease have promoted a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet as most effective in warding off the leading killer of Americans.    But in recent years, new evidence has brought this advice into question.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of heart attack patients fail to take the most important action they can to increase their chances of survival, calling 911, a study has found. Instead, nearly half of the roughly 772,000 Americans who had heart attacks over a four-year period studied either drove themselves to hospitals or had someone take them. The report, in the online version of Circulation, an American Heart Association journal, will be published in the regular journal in January.
docs.abstract: University of Alabama researchers, reporting in online version of American Heart Assn journal Circulation, find that 911 emergency medical service was called in only 53 percent of heart attack cases across US from 1994 to 1998; lead author Dr John G Canto warns that consequences of not calling ambulance can be extremely serious; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Thousands of heart attack patients fail to take the most important action they can to increase their chances of survival, calling 911, a study has found.    Instead, nearly half of the roughly 772,000 Americans who had heart attacks over a four-year...

docs.lead_paragraph: Men who are dedicated mountain bikers may be risking their fertility if they fail to equip the bikes with protective gear, researchers report. Nearly 90 percent of the bikers studied had lower sperm counts and sperm that was less mobile, compared with a group that did not ride the bikes, the study said.
docs.abstract: University Hospital in Innsbruck, Austria, uroradiologist Dr Ferdinand Frauscher, addressing conference of Radiological Society of North America, says nearly 90 percent of avid mountain bikers studied have lower sperm counts and sperm is less mobile; suggests riders equip bikes with wider, padded seats and shock absorbers; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Men who are dedicated mountain bikers may be risking their fertility if they fail to equip the bikes with protective gear, researchers report.     Nearly 90 percent of the bikers studied had lower sperm counts and sperm that was less mobile, compared...

docs.lead_paragraph: Screening men for signs of prostate cancer can be an accurate way to predict the disease, but there is no evidence that it does anything to reduce deaths from the disease, a federal health advisory panel is reporting today. The findings, being published in the journal Annals of Internal Medicine, come from the federal Preventive Services Task Force, which advises the government on health policy.
docs.abstract: US Preventive Services Task Force, in findings to be published in journal Annals of Internal Medicine, reports that screening men for signs of prostate cancer can accurately predict disease but may not reduce number of deaths (M)
docs.snippet: Screening men for signs of prostate cancer can be an accurate way to predict the disease, but there is no evidence that it does anything to reduce deaths from the disease, a federal health advisory panel is reporting today.    The findings, being...

docs.lead_paragraph: High-resolution modern images of the human body and imaginative early attempts to diagram internal organs are on display in an exhibit called ''Dream Anatomy'' at the National Library of Medicine, on the campus of the National Institutes of Health here. The exhibit shows for the first time rare historical anatomical works from the library's collection, as diverse as a 1543 treatise by Andreas Vesalius, known as the father of modern anatomy, and seven-page Plexiglas books that show the internal structures of a man and a woman photographed in cross-sections from head to toe shortly after each died.

headline.main: On Display: An Inside Look at the Body

docs.abstract: National Library of Medicine opens exhibit of high-resolution modern images of human body and rare historical anatomical works from its collection at National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md; photos (M)
docs.snippet: High-resolution modern images of the human body and imaginative early attempts to diagram internal organs are on display in an exhibit called ''Dream Anatomy'' at the National Library of Medicine, on the campus of the National Institutes of Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the first type of antidepressant, and for many people the monamine oxidase, or MAO, inhibitor remains the best hope for relief from major depression. The trouble is that the side effects can be so serious that MAO inhibitors are rarely prescribed. When taken with certain foods, for example, they may bring on sudden and severe hypertension.

headline.main: Patch Raises New Hope For Beating Depression

docs.abstract: Article on study reported in November issue of American Journal of Psychiatry suggesting that administering MAO inhibitor selegiline in patch form gives patients benefits of antidepressant without usual side effects, including sudden and severe hypertension (M)
docs.snippet: It was the first type of antidepressant, and for many people the monamine oxidase, or MAO, inhibitor remains the best hope for relief from major depression.    The trouble is that the side effects can be so serious that MAO inhibitors are rarely...

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies who breast-feed are no less likely to suffer from colic than those who use a bottle, a recent study reports. Writing in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine, researchers said they had abandoned their theory that a baby's diet might be linked to colic.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute, reporting in Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine, reject theory that baby's diet may be linked to colic; say breast-fed babies are no less susceptible to colic than bottle-fed ones; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Babies who breast-feed are no less likely to suffer from colic than those who use a bottle, a recent study reports.    Writing in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine, researchers said they had abandoned their theory that a baby's diet...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''American Normal: The Hidden World of Asperger Syndrome,'' by Lawrence Osborne. Copernicus Books, $27.50. It was an exciting moment for me -- and, I imagine, for other parents of children with the baffling neurological disorder called Asperger syndrome -- when The New York Times Magazine published Lawrence Osborne's ''Little Professor Syndrome'' in June 2000.

headline.main: What's Normal? A Look At Asperger Syndrome

docs.abstract: David Corcoran reviews book American Normal: The Hidden World of Asperger Syndrome by Lawrence Osborne; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I am a recovering child sexual abuser,'' said the lanky 71-year-old man. ''For several years in the early 90's, I abused three of my granddaughters.''

headline.main: To Prevent Sexual Abuse, Abusers Step Forward

docs.abstract: Article on unusual program sponsored by Stop It Now, sexual abuse prevention group based in Haydenville, Mass, in which abusers educate public about sexual abuse and rally adults to act before abuse occurs; experts note that nearly all sexual abuse prevention programs in past two decades have focused on children rather than molesters; drawing; photo; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: ''I am a recovering child sexual abuser,'' said the lanky 71-year-old man. ''For several years in the early 90's, I abused three of my granddaughters.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A middle-aged man collapses on a Manhattan subway platform with a heart attack. Paramedics arrive, and they do all the right things: give him an aspirin to chew, place nitroglycerin under his tongue and administer oxygen through a face mask. Then they take him to a hospital that doesn't perform angioplasty, the procedure that uses tiny balloons and coils of wire called stents to open blockages in the arteries that feed the heart. Angioplasty is the best treatment for a heart attack if performed expeditiously by experienced doctors.
docs.abstract: Drs Sandeep Jauhar and Norma Keller Cases column on ongoing debate over how acute heart attacks should be treated; describes stages of heart attack and immediate need for angioplasty to open blocked arteries; sees need for coordination of ambulance fleets in major cities, including New York, to get victims to hospitals that perform angioplasty (M)
